senses.de: To push or force something or someone away or back.
senses.ex: The scientist uses a magnet to repel metal objects.

Tips.title: Physical Push
Tips.description: Used when an object or person is forced to move away.
Tips.example: Wind turbines can repel birds, pushing them to fly elsewhere.

Tips.title: Magnetic Forces
Tips.description: Refers to how magnets either attract or repel each other.
Tips.example: Like poles of magnets repel, causing them to push apart.

senses.de: To cause someone to feel disgust or dislike.
senses.ex: The sight of blood repels me.

Tips.title: Feeling Disgust
Tips.description: Describes a strong negative reaction to something unpleasant.
Tips.example: I repel at the idea of eating spoiled food.

Tips.title: Emotional Distance
Tips.description: Creates a sense of separation due to discomfort or dislike.
Tips.example: His arrogance repels me from wanting to get to know him.

senses.de: To refuse to accept or agree with something.
senses.ex: She repelled all his attempts at helping her.

Tips.title: Strong Rejection
Tips.description: To strongly decline something, like an offer or idea.
Tips.example: She repelled the notion of dropping out of school.

Tips.title: Unacceptance
Tips.description: Emphasizes refusal to consider or even entertain a thought.
Tips.example: He repelled every solution I suggested for the project.

senses.ex: The army repelled the enemy forces.

Tips.title: Defensive Success
Tips.description: Indicates effective defense against an attack or intrusion.
Tips.example: The fort repelled the invader's attacks all night long.

Tips.title: Action Outcome
Tips.description: Focuses on the successful result of resisting something.
Tips.example: The immune system repels viruses to keep the body healthy.

senses.de: To keep something harmful or unwanted away.

Tips.title: Protection
Tips.description: Keeps something undesirable from affecting or approaching.
Tips.example: Special clothing repels ticks when hiking in the woods.

Tips.title: Prevention
Tips.description: Acts to stop something from happening or getting closer.
Tips.example: Painting a surface with this coat will repel rust formation.

Deter.wordDefinition:
Deter means to discourage someone from doing something. For example, if a sign says a house is protected by a security system, it may deter burglars from attempting to break in.

Deter is used in situations where you want to discourage someone from doing something, while repel is used in situations where you want to push something away.

Disgust.wordDefinition:
Disgust is a feeling of deep dislike and revulsion towards something that is considered to be unpleasant or offensive.

Disgust relates to a feeling of revulsion towards something unpleasant, whereas repel relates to an action of pushing away or avoiding something harmful.

Dispel.wordDefinition:
Dispel means to make something disappear or to get rid of something, usually a feeling, belief or misconception. It is applicable in situations where there is a misunderstanding or a false belief that needs to be corrected or cleared up.

In simpler terms, dispel is like removing a cloud of confusion or uncertainty, while repel is like building a shield to keep something out.

Drive away.wordDefinition:
The words drive away and repel both mean to push something away, but they are used in different contexts. Drive away is used when talking about physically moving something or someone away from a particular place or situation.

For example, a farmer might use a stick to drive away a herd of cows that have wandered into his garden.

So drive away is usually related to physical movement, whereas repel is related to a quality or force that is unattractive or unsuitable.

Expel.wordDefinition:
Expel means to force out someone or something from a place or situation.

It is usually used when someone is expelled from a school or a country. For example, if a student breaks the rules of a school, they can be expelled, which means they are not allowed to attend that school anymore.

Expel is about forcing someone or something out, while repel is about keeping something or someone away.

Fend off.wordDefinition:
The words fend off and repel both mean to defend oneself against an attack, but fend off suggests a more direct and physical action, like using your arms or body to push away the attacker or danger, whereas repel suggests a more indirect or defensive action, like using a repellent substance or strategy to keep the attacker or danger at bay.

Example: If a person was walking in the woods and suddenly faced an attacking bear, they might use their hands or a stick to fend off the bear's attack.

Keep away.wordDefinition:
Both keep away and repel mean to keep something or someone away from a specific place or person.

However, keep away suggests keeping something or someone at a distance, while repel suggests actively driving something or someone away.

For example, you could say "keep away from the edge of the cliff" to warn someone to stay a safe distance from the edge.

You could say "the repellent spray keeps mosquitoes away from me" to describe how the spray actively drives the mosquitoes away from you.

Keep away is more passive and generally used to describe warning or precautionary measures, while repel is more active and describes methods or products that actively push something away.

Repulse.wordDefinition:
Both repel and repulse mean to push away or keep at a distance.

Whereas, repulse is more often used in the sense of causing disgust or aversion, such as the smell of garbage may repulse someone.

Overall, both words mean to push away, but repel suggests rejecting something while repulse suggests disgust.

quotes.Text: I gained this new sense of control over my love life because when I called myself a 'man repeller,' you assumed that being single is my choice. I'm man-repelling because that's how I want to dress. I'm not single because no men like me. I'm single because I choose fashion over a relationship.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Leandra Medine

quotes.Text: The ego mind both professes its desire for love and does everything possible to repel it, or if it gets here anyway, to sabotage it. That is why dealing with issues like control, anger, and neediness is the most important work in preparing ourselves for love.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Marianne Williamson

quotes.Text: Allow the president to invade a neighboring nation whenever he shall deem it necessary to repel an invasion,and you allow him to do so whenever he may choose to say he deems it necessary for such purpose - and you allow him to make war at pleasure.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Abraham Lincoln

quotes.Text: If we desire to avoid insult, we must be able to repel it; if we desire to secure peace, one of the most powerful instruments of our rising prosperity, it must be known, that we are at all times ready for War.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: George Washington

quotes.Text: I guess I'm attracted and repelled by isolation. It scares me. And it's why I tend to write about older characters, too, because for them the stakes are somewhat higher.
quotes.Title: Irish Playwright
quotes.Name: Conor McPherson

quotes.Text: We have all said things that are offensive when taken out of context. You don't need to tell the public to be repelled. They will tell you they are repelled.
quotes.Title: English Comedian
quotes.Name: Lee Mack

quotes.Text: I tell girls all the time that the men that have fallen in love with me, have all fallen during a man repeller stage... funny how life works out like that.
quotes.Title: American Designer
quotes.Name: Rachel Roy

quotes.Text: I certainly don't follow fashion. I think fashion, as far as the industry and the whole world that surrounds it, is quite vile, and I'm repelled by it.
quotes.Title: British Musician
quotes.Name: Mika

quotes.Text: What distinguished my life from my brother's is that my mother didn't like me. When I became a woman, I seemed to repel her.
quotes.Title: Novelist
quotes.Name: Jamaica Kincaid

quotes.Text: I'm not afraid of heights. I rock climb. I can repel off the side of a building.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Kate Hudson
